intro: Corchorus cunninghamii, commonly known as the mountain spinach, is a perennial herb native to Australia. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its erect, branched stems and palmate leaves. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in clusters, which are followed by distinctive, spiny capsules containing seeds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in swampy or wetland areas. Its leaves are edible and have been used in traditional Aboriginal diets.
